Leader of the
Oslo
Conservatives

(born 12 June 1978) is a Norwegian politician representing the
Conservative Party.
He served as Minister of Local Government from 2020 to 2021.
[
1
]
Previously he served as the Minister of International Development from 2018 to 2019 in
Prime Minister
Erna Solberg's cabinet, being the first since
Heikki Holmås
from 2012 to 2013. In 2019, he also became the first Minister of Digitalisation after the
Christian Democratic Party
joined the Cabinet, a post he served in until 2020.
Education
[
edit
]
Astrup graduated from
Institut Le

(born 12 June 1978) is a Norwegian politician representing the
Conservative Party.

supporting_quotes: leader of the Conservative Party in Oslo in 2012

quotes: Rosey with an International General Certificate of Secondary Education (1995)
Berg Upper Secondary School with an International Baccalaureate (1997)
Astrup worked in management consulting at Arkwright from 2000 until 2002
Between 2001 and 2008 he was the editor of the conservative periodical Minerva
political adviser to the Governing Mayor of Oslo Erling Lae from 2008 until 2009
Astrup was elected Member of Parliament in 2009
leader of the Conservative Party in Oslo in 2012
He was re-elected as leader of the Oslo Conservative Party in 2014 and 2016
stepping down in 2018, when he was succeeded by Heidi Nordby Lunde
Ahead of the election in 2013 Astrup was nominated as the second candidate for Oslo
after the 2017 election
He held this position until his government appointment in January 2018
Astrup sat on the Standing Committee on Energy and the Environment from 2009 to 2015
from 2016 to 2017 he chaired the Standing Committee on Transport and Communication
After the election in 2017 he was appointed chair of the Standing Committee on Finance
Following the cabinet's defeat at the 2021 election

(born 12 June 1978) is a Norwegian politician representing the
Conservative Party.

supporting_quotes: After the Christian Democratic Party entered government on 22 January 2019, Astrup was appointed minister of digitalisation, the first of its kind.
events.notes: Clear linkage between time, organization, and role.

quotes: He became the party's financial spokesperson following the 2025 election.
Following Erna Solberg's resignation as party leader following the 2025 parliamentary election, Astrup was considered one of the favourite candidates to succeed her.
He officially announced his candidacy in October, stating that the party 'needs to find back to itself'.
Astrup entered the Solberg cabinet in 2018 as minister of international development, a post he held until 2019.
Astrup entered the Solberg cabinet in 2018 as minister of international development, a post he held until 2019.
In his capacity as minister, Astrup was appointed by United Nations Secretary General António Guterres in 2018 to the High-level Panel on Digital Cooperation, co-chaired by Melinda Gates and Jack Ma.
After the Christian Democratic Party entered government on 22 January 2019, Astrup was appointed minister of digitalisation, the first of its kind.
After the Progress Party withdrew from government in January 2020, Astrup was appointed minister of local government, succeeding Monica Mæland, who had been appointed minister of justice.
In 2022, Astrup was Norway's candidate to succeed Susanna Moorehead as chair of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Development Assistance Committee.

quotes: Following the Liberal Party's entrance into the Solberg cabinet, Astrup was appointed minister of international development, the first person to hold the post in five years.

supporting_quotes: In 2019, he became the first Minister of Digitalisation.
The Minister for Digitization is responsible for ICT policy in the Ministry of Local Government and Modernization.
The minister is also responsible for electronic communication at the Ministry of Transport and Communications, including the responsibility for the National Communications Authority.
In addition, the Minister is responsible for Altinn, business-oriented ICT, Digital21, and resources for ICT research in the Ministry of Trade and Fisheries.
events.notes: Multiple organizations mentioned as part of the responsibilities of the Minister of Digitalisation.

label.label: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
label.organization: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
label.involvement: Chair of the Development Assistance Committee.
label.reasoning: Leadership role in a major international organization indicates significant global influence.

supporting_quotes: In 2022, Astrup was Norway's candidate to succeed Susanna Moorehead as chair of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Development Assistance Committee.
events.notes: Clear linkage between time, organizations, and role.

quotes: He became the party's financial spokesperson following the 2025 election.
Following Erna Solberg's resignation as party leader following the 2025 parliamentary election, Astrup was considered one of the favourite candidates to succeed her.
He officially announced his candidacy in October, stating that the party 'needs to find back to itself'.
Astrup entered the Solberg cabinet in 2018 as minister of international development, a post he held until 2019.
Astrup entered the Solberg cabinet in 2018 as minister of international development, a post he held until 2019.
In his capacity as minister, Astrup was appointed by United Nations Secretary General António Guterres in 2018 to the High-level Panel on Digital Cooperation, co-chaired by Melinda Gates and Jack Ma.
After the Christian Democratic Party entered government on 22 January 2019, Astrup was appointed minister of digitalisation, the first of its kind.
After the Progress Party withdrew from government in January 2020, Astrup was appointed minister of local government, succeeding Monica Mæland, who had been appointed minister of justice.
In 2022, Astrup was Norway's candidate to succeed Susanna Moorehead as chair of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Development Assistance Committee.
